items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight with dozens ofÂ bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales with more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Police say some fires are being deliberately lit, as emergency services minister condemns 'absolute nongs'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kirsten Webster Police are investigating a series of suspicious fires in the Gold Coast Hinterland yesterday. Emergency crews were called to fires in grassland near Waltham Court, Bonogin Road and Brighton Lane between 2:45pm and 4:10pm yesterday. Initial investigations indicate the fires were deliberately lit. Anyone who was in the area or who has dashcam footage, is urged to contact police. The federal Emergency Services Minister Murray Watt says arsonists are putting people in danger. "It is so unfortunate that every fire season we see absolute nongs going around deliberately lighting fires that put other people at risk, of course if these people are caught they will be charged."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Absolute nongs': Police investigating Gold Coast fires

children.content: (ABC News: Steve Keen)
Reporting by Kirsten Webster
Police are investigating a series of suspicious fires in the Gold Coast Hinterland yesterday.
Emergency crews were called to fires in grassland near Waltham Court, Bonogin Road and Brighton Lane between 2:45pm and 4:10pm yesterday.
Initial investigations indicate the fires were deliberately lit.
Anyone who was in the area or who has dashcam footage, is urged to contact police.
The
federal Emergency Services Minister Murray Watt
says arsonists are putting people in danger.
"It is so unfortunate that every fire season we see absolute nongs going around deliberately lighting fires that put other people at risk, of course if these people are caught they will be charged."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The premier said in a statement the emergency was not yet over despite conditions easing slightly overnight. "Although the loss of property in these fires is significant, 387 homes have been saved. "This is a tribute to our firefighters and the communities who continue to follow their directions. "There is no doubt these combined efforts have saved lives. "For those who have lost everything, the arms of Queenslanders are wrapping around them. "More than 670 people have received emergency assistance payments so far with more on the way." The statement said: Since October 21, fire crews have fought 900 vegetation fires 83 firefighters from Victoria have started arriving 42 aircraft available today There are currently 81 bushfires burning across the state.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says 387 homes have been saved

children.content: (X: Annastacia Palaszczuk)
The premier said in a statement the emergency was not yet over despite conditions easing slightly overnight.
"Although the loss of property in these fires is significant, 387 homes have been saved.
"This is a tribute to our firefighters and the communities who continue to follow their directions.
"There is no doubt these combined efforts have saved lives.
"For those who have lost everything, the arms of Queenslanders are wrapping around them.
"More than 670 people have received emergency assistance payments so far with more on the way."
The statement said:
Since October 21, fire crews have fought 900 vegetation fires
83 firefighters from Victoria have started arriving
42 aircraft available today
There are currently 81 bushfires burning across the state.
Helicopters made "at least a dozen" drops to pick up water from a private lake just metres from homes at Witta on Tuesday.
(Supplied: Jean-Marie Latino)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Inspector Grant Marcus says police believe a bushfire that destroyed two homes at Goodwood, south of Bundaberg, was deliberately lit. "People have lost houses as a result of someone lighting a fire," he said. "People have lost sheds and machinery, schools have had to be evacuated. "We've got a lot of cost and damage to our community."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bushfire that destroyed two homes at Goodwood was deliberately lit, police say

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to Israel over its war in Gaza, President Gustavo Petro said in a post on X on Tuesday. "I have decided to recall our ambassador to Israel. If Israel does not stop the massacre of the Palestinian people we cannot stay there," he said. Chile also recalled its ambassador for consultations after what it described as Israel's violations of international humanitarian law stemming from its recent military attacks on Gaza. "Chile strongly condemns and observes with great concern... these military operations," the South American nation's foreign ministry said in a statement. Chile said Israel's operations amounted to "collective punishment" of Gaza's Palestinian civilian population, the ministry said. It also called for: An immediate end to hostilities The release of hostages held by Hamas militants who control Gaza To allow the transit of humanitarian aid for Gazans The two countries' criticism of Israel's attacks on Gaza follow the move by Bolivia to break ties with Israel, citing "crimes against humanity." Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Colombia, Chile recall Israel ambassadors

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, a spokesperson for the Israeli Defense Force (IDF) doubled down on their claim that their strike on the Jabalia refugee camp in Northern Gaza was targeting a legitimate combat zone. Colonel Jonathan Conricus, IDF's international spokesperson, confirmed they were behind a deadly air strike, which they claim has killed a top Hamas commander. "There was no strike on a refugee camp," he told ABC's Patricia Karvelas. "We targeted a Hamas battalion commander, a very important combatant who was leading combat operations against us. "He was hiding together with many of his terrorists, his combatants in a tunnel complex underneath civilian houses, underneath the street." Earlier, we reported that an IDF statement said the strike on Jabalia, Gaza's largest refugee camp, had killed Ibrahim Biari. Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem has denied any senior commander was there and called the claim an Israeli pretext for killing civilians. "I can confirm that he has been killed, and so have many terrorists. That was the aim of what we have done," Colonel Conricus told the ABC. "I understand that there are reports of civilian casualties. I want to emphasise the civilians are not our targets â we focus on Hamas. "And it is because of Hamas practices of using women and children and civilians as their human shields that there are casualties." The Hamas-run health ministry and a hospital director say at least 50 civilians were also killed. UN Special Rapporteur for the Palestinian Territories, Francesca Albanese, responded directly to the claim, saying the Israeli strike on Jabalia could constitute a crime against humanity. "A refugee camp inhabited by 400 cannot be a legitimate military target, and this cannot be justified. If it is it might be an extermination, which constituted a crime against humanity under international law," she told RN Breakfast. Follow the link below to listen to the interview:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF says it targeted a Hamas 'battalion commander', UN says refugee camp is 'not a legitimate military target'

featuredLink.title: 'This is a combat zone': IDF confirms refugee camp air strike - ABC listen

children.content: Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, a spokesperson for the Israeli Defense Force (IDF) doubled down on their claim that their strike on the Jabalia refugee camp in Northern Gaza was targeting a legitimate combat zone.
Colonel Jonathan Conricus, IDF's international spokesperson,
Â
confirmed they were behind a deadly air strike, which they claim has killed a top Hamas commander.
"There was no strike on a refugee camp," he told ABC's Patricia Karvelas.
"We targeted a Hamas battalion commander, a very important combatant who was leading combat operations against us.
"He was hiding together with many of his terrorists, his combatants in a tunnel complex underneath civilian houses, underneath the street."
Earlier, we reported that an IDF statement said the strike on Jabalia, Gaza's largest refugee camp, had killed Ibrahim Biari.
Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem has denied any senior commander was there and called the claim an Israeli pretext for killing civilians.
"I can confirm that he has been killed, and so have many terrorists. That was the aim of what we have done," Colonel Conricus told the ABC.
"I understand that there are reports of civilian casualties. I want to emphasise the civilians are not our targets â we focus on Hamas.
"And it is because of Hamas practices of using women and children and civilians as their human shields that there are casualties."
The Hamas-run health ministry and a hospital director say at least 50 civilians were also killed.
UN Special Rapporteur for the Palestinian Territories, Francesca Albanese, responded directly to the claim, saying the Israeli strike on Jabalia could constitute a crime against humanity.

"A refugee camp inhabited by 400 cannot be a legitimate military target, and this cannot be justified. If it is it might be an extermination, which constituted a crime against humanity under international law," she told RN Breakfast.
Follow the link below to listen to the interview:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rafah border crossing will be opened on Wednesday for a number of Palestinians who were injured in Gaza to complete their treatment in Egyptian hospitals, Egyptian medical and security sources said. It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this. "We are intensely focused on getting the gate open. "We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah crossing to be opened for injured Gazans to complete treatment in Egypt

children.content: The
Rafah border crossing
will be opened on Wednesday for a number of
Palestinians who were injured in Gaza
to complete their treatment in
Egyptian hospitals
, Egyptian medical and security sources said.
It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza.
State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this.
"We are intensely focused on getting the gate open.
"We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said.
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian government 10-year bonds have been on a run over the past couple of weeks, as expectations of at least one more Reserve Bank interest rate rise mount. According to Refinitiv data, markets are now pricing about a two-thirds chance of the RBA hiking next Tuesday. Bloomberg data has those odds closer to 56% for a rate hike, but also indicates that markets have almost fully priced in two more hikes by the middle of next year to take the cash rate to 4.6%, not just one and done. Expectations of longer term risk free interest rates are even higher, with the Australian 10-year bond closing in on passing 5% for the first time since 2011. The Australian 10-year bond (white line) has now punched above the US benchmark rate (blue line), as local rate expectations are now higher than those for further Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Fed is currently meeting, with the outcome to be announced tomorrow morning Australian time. The current target Fed funds rate in the US is 5.25-5.5%. The market is pricing in almost no chance of a rate rise at this meeting, and just 25% at the December meeting. It's also pricing in a slim chance of rate cuts as early as March and the likelihood of rate cuts by July next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian 10-year bond yields overtake US, head towards 5%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Washington-based International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Reserve Bank to lift interest rates further. Using its annual report into the Australian economy, the fund said that although inflation was easing, it was still too high. The RBA board meets next Tuesday, with most economists and financial markets forecasting that the cash rate will be increased by 0.25 per cent to a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent. The fund said while fiscal policy was working in line with monetary policy, higher interest rates would be necessary to bring down inflation, which has eased to 5.4 per cent but remains well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target band. "While headline inflation has peaked, its decline is slow and core inflation remains sticky," the IMF said in a statement. "The authorities have implemented several policy measures which have significantly contributed to stabilizing the economy and reducing inflation, but staff assess that more is needed to bring inflation back to target and keep inflation expectations anchored. "Continued coordination between fiscal and monetary policy is key to achieving a soft landing, while alleviating the impact of policy tightening on vulnerable households." It called on the federal government and state and territory governments to "implement public investment projects at a more measured and coordinated pace, given supply constraints, to alleviate inflationary pressures and support the RBA's disinflation efforts". "Otherwise, interest rates would have to be even higher, putting the burden of adjustment disproportionately on mortgage holders," it said. Building on recent reforms, it said policymakers should continue their efforts to address climate change and need to do more to boost productivity.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IMF says Australia needs higher interest rates

children.content: The Washington-based International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Reserve Bank to lift interest rates further.
Using its annual report into the Australian economy, the fund said that although inflation was easing, it was still too high.
The RBA board meets next Tuesday, with most economists and financial markets forecasting that the cash rate will be increased by 0.25 per cent to a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent.

The fund said while fiscal policy was working in line with monetary policy, higher interest rates would be necessary to bring down inflation, which has eased to 5.4 per cent but remains well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target band.
"While headline inflation has peaked, its decline is slow and core inflation remains sticky," the IMF said in a statement.
The IMF says Australia needs to keep raising rates.
(Jonathan Ernst: Reuters)

"The authorities have implemented several policy measures which have significantly contributed to stabilizing the economy and reducing inflation, but staff assess that more is needed to bring inflation back to target and keep inflation expectations anchored.
"Continued coordination between fiscal and monetary policy is key to achieving a soft landing, while alleviating the impact of policy tightening on vulnerable households."

It called on the federal government and state and territory governments to "implement public investment projects at a more measured and coordinated pace, given supply constraints, to alleviate inflationary pressures and support the RBA's disinflation efforts".
"Otherwise, interest rates would have to be even higher, putting the burden of adjustment disproportionately on mortgage holders," it said.
Building on recent reforms, it said policymakers should continue their efforts to address climate change and need to do more to boost productivity.
